results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. Part one is of the Gadsden family farm ‘Mooltunya’ in country Victoria. The filmmaker’s wife Jess Gadsden attends her horses, dressed for the farm in gumboots and one of her many headscarfs (seen throughout the films).

The second part contains a family holiday to Alice Springs and surrounding areas which Ronald introduces by filming from a light plane on the approach to the Outback. Their first stop is to Flynn’s Grave memorial for John Flynn who among other achievements for the Outback, lobbied for what would become the Flying Doctor Service. Ronald’s camera shows an appreciation for the landscape they travel through – eucalypts, wildflowers and bees, bushland, rocks formations, dusty roads and the rock wallabies at the MacDonnell Ranges and Uluru. The reel shows a snapshot of Alice Springs in 1978, cars – kombi vans, utes and sedans, seventies fashion including clogs, denim skirts, flares and sunglasses. There are sequences of horseback riding through the bush where Mrs Gadsden shows her prowess among less confident riders and climbing Uluru.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:22:00 huge boulders sitting either side of a shed
00:07:17:00 goanna on rocks
00:8:16:00 to 00:09:00:00 wing span and over Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:10:07:00 ancient Aboringinal rock paintings
00:11:40:00 walking up Uluru (Ayre’s Rock at that time)
00:12:30:00 Ronald and family climb Uluru and find the descent difficult – reinforced by sign warning of the dangers of the climb.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 145]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows yachts sailing around a spot in (most probably) Port Phillip Bay and a school swimming competition.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:04:19:00 yachts racing
00:04:39:00 boats and yachts berthed on the sand
00:04:40:00 single person yachts on the water
00:03:03:00 indoor pool and swimmers
00:03:15:00 students assembling by the pool in readiness for swimming
00:03:18:00 swimmers in competition
00:03:58:00 relay in the pool

results.title: [Douglas Wilson Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Douglas Wilson (1919–1980) was an amateur filmmaker whose films are a snapshot of Australia in the 1950s to 1960s. Douglas’s home movies captured aspects of life in Australia’s major cities as well as in regional areas, often with a focus on public areas, transport or infrastructure projects. A collection of his films has been donated to ACMI by a member of Douglas’s family.

The first part of this film briefly shows an outdoor art show before moving on to water ski jumping on the Yarra River – both are part of the ‘Moomba’ celebrations. The second part shows a road trip from Glenroy to Macedon ending at ‘Cameron Lodge’, Macedon all in Victoria.

Good views of the water ski jumping and the crowds watching from the banks. The road trip shows excellent views of small towns such as Keilor and Diggers Rest, vehicles passing on country roads and roadside scenes including telegraph poles.

Extensive views of the gardens of Cameron Lodge in Macedon including the rotunda, lake, stepping stones and family scenes in the garden.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00:00 outdoor art show
00:00:44:00 Yarra River
00:01:00:00 the ‘Moomba’ festival on the riverbank
00:01:14:00 water skiing
00:02:00:00 water skiing over a jump
00:02:30:00 crowd watching from riverbank
00:03:40:00 title card ‘Glenroy to Macedon 4-3-61’
00:03:47:00 footage of car trip filmed from moving car showing country roads
00:04:38:00 car parked next to Keilor road sign. Good views of cars on road including VW beetle and Holdens, views of telegraph poles
00:05:05:00 road bridge with curved arch
00:05:10:00 ‘Keilor Hotel’ and parked cars, street scenes
00:05:20:00 Diggers Rest town scenes
00:05:40:00 countryside from moving car
00:06:35:00 Jacksons Creek bridge
00:07:28:00 small town with parked Holdens and BP service station
00:07:46:00 title card ‘Cameron Lodge Macedon 4-3-61’
00:07:52:00 views of Cameron Lodge and man walking in gardens
00:08:24:00 views of garden rotunda
00:08:37:00 two women and baby in lodge garden
00:08:40:00 man photographing garden
00:08:47:00 man in rotunda surrounded by lake, crossing stepping stones
00:09:21:00 group walk through lush vegetation including tree ferns
00:09:46:00 walking through lodge garden
00:10:03:00 children playing in rotunda and on stepping stones
00:10:46:00 group of children and adults on lakeside steps
00:11:10:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 19]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 19 shows a pageant held in Melbourne in the Queen’s honour, and preparations for the royal couple’s departure.

Detailed Description Reel 19:

Opens with Title “Floral Pageant Monday, March 8th. 1954” followed by close-ups of pageant participants and floats - some people in “ethnic” and historical costumes to 00:01:08:00 (at 00:00:50:00 close-up of musicians in blackface). 00:01:09:00 floats and performers parade along Melbourne street (probably St Kilda Road, with the camera probably located at the now Domain Road / St Kilda Road intersection). Some of the named floats shown are: “City of Caulfield”, “Department of Supply”, “Victorian Banjo Club”, “Save the Children Fund”, and “Melbourne & Metropolitan Board of Works”. 00:03:45:00 aerial shot of the parade moving along Swanston Street. 00:03:52:00 Title “Official Departure Tuesday, 9th. March, 1954” followed by footage of the preparations for departure - including uniformed personnel parading, luggage being unloaded from car, staff boarding plane (labelled “Qantas Empire Airways”), officials arriving and the waiting crowd.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the 1977 National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW.

Members of the Gadsden family were keen skiers and most of this film is taken up with downhill skiing competitions in which the they would take part. The camera captures the speed and difficulty of the downwards skiing in the competition and indecently shows contemporary snowfield fashions.

There are also scenes of the ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’ and surrounds including a steaming pool, chalets and mountains in the background, as well as some of the Gadsdens and their cars.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:17:00:00 sign ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’

The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the 1977 National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW.

Members of the Gadsden family were keen skiers and most of this film is taken up with downhill skiing competitions in which the they would take part. The camera captures the speed and difficulty of the downwards skiing in the competition and indecently shows contemporary snowfield fashions.

There are also scenes of the ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’ and surrounds including a steaming pool, chalets and mountains in the background, as well as some of the Gadsdens and their cars.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:17:00:00 sign ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’

The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the 1977 National Titles skiing competition at Thredbo in NSW.

There are also scenes of the ‘Thredbo Alpine Hotel’ and surrounds including a steaming pool, chalets and mountains in the background, as well as some of the Gadsdens and their cars.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: A Journey to a new land
results.creator_credit: Tuan Anh Tran, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Leaving family and escaping from Vietnam in 1978 and eventually arriving in Australia by boat as a refugee, it would be six years before Tuan Anh Tran could finally be reunited with his family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tuan Anh Tran, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: China tour
results.creator_credit: Si Tuan Lieng, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Si Tuan Lieng and his wife are retirees and have recently made an overseas trip to China. In this story he talks about his life and family, their integration into Australian society since they left Vietnam over 26 years ago and highlights of their holiday in China.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Si Tuan Lieng, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
